new_entries.title: 🛠 Private Infra Ready: Copilot Coding Agent + Your Self-Hosted Runners (Public Preview)
new_entries.content: Copilot coding agent can now run its development environment on your own infrastructure using self-hosted GitHub Actions runners managed by Actions Runner Controller (ARC). That means agent tasks can reach internal packages, private build tooling, or on-prem services that aren’t exposed to the public internet—while still remaining ephemeral, isolated, and automated. 🤖 What This Unlocks Use internal dependency registries or artifact stores (npm, Maven, PyPI mirrors, etc.). Run tests against services only reachable inside your network. Apply existing compliance / observability layers already baked into your runner fleet. Keep Copilot’s environment disposable—every task starts clean, ends clean. 🧩 How It Works (Recap) Copilot coding agent executes tasks in a GitHub Actions-powered environment. By default we provision hosted runners. Now you can override the environment via copilot-setup-steps.yml and target an ARC scale set. 🔧 Setup Steps Deploy ARC and create a scale set: Quickstart: https://docs.github.com/actions/tutorials/use-actions-runner-controller/quickstart Edit copilot-setup-steps.yml in the repository (or org standard) to point to your scale set via runs-on:. Commit & delegate a task to Copilot coding agent—your agent now boots on your infra. jobs: copilot-setup-steps: runs-on: arc-scale-set-name steps: uses: actions/checkout@v4 Add any setup your internal environment needs name: Install private deps run: npm ci 🛡️ Security & Isolation Notes Each task still uses an ephemeral workspace—no state leakage between tasks. Your existing runner-level security policies (network ACLs, scanning, logging) apply automatically. Keep secrets management consistent with other ARC-based workflows. ✅ Recommended First Uses Internal SDK refactors Dependency upgrades needing private registry access Integration tests hitting staging APIs behind a firewall Legacy monorepo tasks with custom internal toolchains 📎 Tips Standardize a base copilot-setup-steps.yml template at the org level for consistency. Include lightweight caching if internal dependency retrieval is slow. Pair with CodeQL & secret scanning already built into coding agent for layered protection. 📘 Learn More Customizing agent environment ARC quickstart 💬 Feedback Let us know what’s missing—metrics visibility? multi-arch scale sets? runner health telemetry surfaced in the agent summary? Drop ideas in comments below: Bring Copilot to where your code actually lives. 🔐

new_entries.title: Custom agents for GitHub Copilot
new_entries.content: Custom agents for GitHub Copilot make it easy for users and organizations to specialize their Copilot coding agent (CCA) through simple, file-based configurations. By adding a configuration file under .github/agents in a repository or in the {org}/.github repository, you can define agent personas that capture your team’s workflows, conventions, and unique needs. These agents can be further tailored with prompts, tool selections, and Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to optimize for specific use cases. Anyone using GitHub Copilot can define and use custom agents, whether you’re an individual developer, part of a team, or managing an organization. Custom agents work across Copilot coding agent in github.com, the Copilot CLI, and will be coming to a future release of Visual Studio Code. Key benefits Define agent specializations that act like focused teammates, using prompts and tool selections unique to your workflow. Add organization-specific or team-specific agents by placing configuration files in a known location in your repository or organization settings. Refine agent behaviors beyond standard Copilot instructions, making it easier to enforce coding conventions, compliance, or custom automations. Enable agents to use custom tools and MCP servers, giving you fine-grained control over how tasks are completed. Get started quickly by adding a simple markdown file. There’s no need for a separate installation or complex setup. Examples Imagine a frontend engineer subagent that enforces team conventions for React or Vue, or an agent that uses a custom MCP to automate additional tasks with the GitHub CLI. With custom agents, you can define these behaviors in a central file, making them easily accessible and maintainable. Not sure where to begin? Some of our awesome partners have created custom agents to help you improve your workflow. You can find those and more sample agents at @github/awesome-copilot. 🌟Leave a comment! Learn more by reading our docs on custom agents and join the discussion by leaving feedback in the comments below!

new_entries.title: Managing Copilot Business in enterprise is now generally available
new_entries.content: Enterprise owners with GitHub Enterprise Cloud can assign Copilot Business licenses inside an enterprise account independent of granting any organizational access. This experience provides a flexible, more scalable Copilot Business licensing model to enterprises without requiring a GitHub Enterprise Cloud license per user. To assign Copilot Business licenses through an enterprise account, your users will need to already exist in the enterprise, whether as a preexisting organization member or as an unaffiliated user. Whether you assign to the user directly or through an enterprise team, enterprise owners can use the dedicated Copilot Business licensing page to assign these licenses. If a user is assigned both through an organization and through the enterprise directly, they will only consume one license, and they will have access to the highest Copilot license assigned to them. The new dedicated licensing page provides enterprise owners with: An overview of current Copilot license consumption in the enterprise. A centralized place to enable Copilot across the enterprise and its organizations. The ability to manage Copilot Business direct assignments across users and enterprise teams. For new enterprises who start with our GitHub trial, the experience has been updated to allow enterprise owners to try out this new licensing experience on day one. Enterprise owners can convert their trial with only the Copilot Business licenses assigned at the enterprise license and add in GitHub Enterprise Cloud licenses later as needed. To learn more, read our documentation on Copilot Business licensing, Enterprise Teams, and unaffiliated users. 🌟Leave a comment! Join the discussion and leave feedback in the comments below!

new_entries.title: Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API in public preview
new_entries.content: The AI era of software development isn’t about are teams using AI, but rather how well are they using it? The GitHub Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API, now in public preview for GitHub Enterprise customers using Copilot, helps you answer that question with data. You can now see how Copilot adoption and engagement in the IDE varies across both your enterprise and your users to understand who’s using it, where, and how. What’s included in the public preview The Copilot usage metrics dashboard gives enterprise administrators and billing managers direct visibility into Copilot usage and adoption under the Insights tab. The dashboard provides an aggregated enterprise view, while the NDJSON download or API offer user-level granularity for deeper analysis. In this public preview, you’ll find metrics including: Daily and weekly active users across GitHub Copilot IDE modes, including agent mode. Agent adoption across your user base. Lines of code added and deleted across all IDE modes. Language and model usage patterns across IDEs. These metrics help you understand: Overall usage and adoption: Review indicators like weekly usage provide a broad view of Copilot adoption across your enterprise. Specific model, feature, and language usage: See which AI models and programming languages are most utilized by your teams, highlighting areas for even greater value. Agent adoption percentage: Track how many developers are using Copilot for advanced tasks like refactoring, debugging, and complex problem solving. High agent adoption signals a shift toward truly transformative coding. Together, these are foundational metrics showing who’s adopting Copilot, how consistently, and what that usage looks like across your enterprise. How to enable Copilot usage metrics in your enterprise By default, Copilot usage metrics are disabled unless your enterprise participated in the private preview, in which case they remain enabled. Enterprise admins can enable them as follows: Navigate to your AI Controls tab on github.com. Select Copilot in the left sidebar. Scroll down to the "Metrics" section where you’ll see Copilot usage metrics. Change the Copilot usage metrics policy setting to Enabled. This will enable the Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API for your enterprise, allowing enterprise administrators and billing managers to view usage and adoption data. Once enabled, you can access the Copilot usage metrics dashboard directly from the Insights tab at the enterprise level or through the Enterprise and user-level API. Learn more View the Copilot usage metrics dashboard documentation. Explore the Copilot usage metrics API. Join us in the comments below to share your feedback and ask questions. Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

new_entries.title: Copilot Generates Commit Messages on .com [GA]
new_entries.content: GitHub Copilot now offers contextual commit message suggestions for file changes made on github.com—making lightweight documentation an effortless, integrated part of every commit. This feature was previously in public preview and is now generally available to all Copilot users. 🎉 When enabled, Copilot automatically suggests a concise, relevance‑focused summary of the changes you made through the file editor on github.com. Deleting a file continues to use the existing default: Delete <filename> Adding a new file with no contents continues to use the existing default: Add <filename> Enabling Copilot-generated commit messages Copilot-generated commit messages are available to users on all GitHub Copilot plans (including Free, Pro/Pro+, Business, and Enterprise). Individuals: You can opt out at any time via the “Copilot‑generated commit messages” toggle in your Copilot settings. Enterprises & organizations (including GitHub Enterprise Cloud with data residency): Administrators can opt in through enterprise administrator settings. Enterprises already opted into public preview features are automatically enabled for Copilot-generated commit messages. Commit metadata rulesets: If your enterprise has rulesets enforcing commit metadata, you will still see a default commit message for commits made in organization‑related repositories where those restrictions apply. Your Feedback Matters Join us in the comments below to share feedback, ask questions, or suggest improvements. Start using Copilot-generated commit messages today and keep your commit history clean, consistent, and informative—without the extra friction.

new_entries.title: Instant semantic code search indexing for GitHub Copilot
new_entries.content: GitHub Copilot now features Instant semantic code search indexing! This dramatically reduces indexing time from approximately 5 minutes to just a few seconds (maximum 60 seconds in some cases). Semantic Code Search, one of GitHub Copilot's most powerful capabilities, enables Copilot to: Provide responses specific to your codebase's architecture and patterns. Reference existing functions, classes, and implementations in your repo. Suggest code that aligns with your project's style and conventions. new_entries.title: Scale Institutional Knowledge with GitHub Copilot Spaces and Agents
new_entries.content: TL;DR Scattered tribal knowledge throttles onboarding, cross-team work, and agent outcomes. Copilot pulls trusted context into the flow of work so everyone ships faster. Pair Copilot Spaces, Coding Agent, Agent Mode, and Copilot Code Review to hit the big four wins: faster time-to-first-PR, fewer interrupts to senior engineers, consistent patterns, and stronger autonomous results. Below you’ll find an urgency hook, discovery prompts, a pilot plan, objection handling, and a resource stack that keeps knowledge current in IDEs, PRs, and automated workflows. Why this matters The average large U.S. business loses $47M every year to inefficient knowledge sharing; workers burn ~5.3 hours a week searching for answers or recreating past work.[^1][^2] A 1,000-person knowledge workforce can waste $2.5–$3.5M annually hunting for non-existent or hard-to-find info—plus ~$15M in opportunity cost.[^3] Developers spend ~17 hours/week on maintenance and ~4 hours/week on “bad code,” implying ~$85B in global productivity drag.[^4] Better knowledge sharing boosts knowledge-worker productivity by 20–25%.[^5] Use these proof points to frame a 30–90 day pilot with execs who care about onboarding speed, duplicate work, and senior focus time. Who to target Customers with onboarding friction, siloed standards, or inconsistent practices—anywhere “How do I…?” questions slow delivery. Ideal customer profile: New devs take 1–3 months to land their first meaningful PRs; leadership cites long waits for the first three PRs.[^6] Know-how sits in experts’ heads or outdated wikis; “Where’s the doc?” pings flood Slack/Teams. Standards vary by squad, resulting in duplicated implementations and frequent “please follow the guidelines” PR nudges. Senior ICs lose deep-work hours answering basic Q&A. Signals to look for: No clear single source of truth for architecture, APIs, runbooks, or conventions. High time-to-first-PR for new hires; constant interrupts to senior engineers. Evidence of reinvented solutions, missed standards, or quality regressions in PRs. Talk track: discovery + business framing Start by uncovering where knowledge breaks today: “What questions do new developers ask repeatedly?” “Where do developers go for onboarding or when they’re stuck?” “Which standards do teams most often miss, rediscover, or debate?” “How do you provide trusted, customized knowledge to AI tools or agents today?” “How do you keep documentation from going stale?” Reframe the answers in business terms: Faster onboarding → reduce time-to-first-PR by giving new hires a Space that “knows your systems.” Fewer interrupts → senior engineers regain focus time as common questions resolve inside the IDE or chat. Consistency and quality → everyone follows the same vetted examples, cutting defects and rework. Agent-ready → via MCP, the same vetted context powers internal tools and autonomous agents. Three ways Copilot scales institutional knowledge Embedded best practices in the flow of work Copilot completions, chat answers, and code review comments reflect org-wide standards, repo idioms, and golden-path snippets. New contributors code like they’ve already internalized the expert playbook. Reduced dependency on gatekeepers Spaces curate live code, runbooks, standards, and how-tos. Copilot surfaces context proactively so developers don’t need to “tap the shoulder” of a veteran teammate. Faster onboarding and continuous knowledge transfer Domain language, framework nuances, and migration recipes appear where work happens—IDE, PRs, agent prompts—so knowledge sharing is real time, not quarterly training. Step-by-step pilot plan (30–90 days) Phase What to do Outcome Identify the opportunity Baseline time-to-first-PR for recent hires, volume of repeated Q&A, duplicated work examples; tie the pain to delayed features, lost senior capacity, or quality hits. Clear urgency + ROI hypothesis. Introduce Copilot Spaces Stand up a Space for one flagship product; attach live repos, key docs, concise standards/how-tos. Run a hands-on demo answering real questions with linked sources. Optionally show how an internal agent would query the Space via MCP. Stakeholders see trusted answers in context. Define success Set a concrete goal (e.g., cut TTFPR by 20% in 60–90 days, halve senior interrupts). Document the owner and success plan. Shared pilot scorecard. Track usage and impact Monitor Space analytics (queries/day, unique users, top topics). Capture user quotes. Measure outcome deltas vs. baseline: onboarding speed, repeat questions, standard violations. Evidence that knowledge flows improved. Prove business outcomes Translate results for execs: regained senior capacity, faster delivery, improved consistency. Recommend scaling to additional domains, onboarding flows, and agent workflows. Expansion path + budget request. Example flow summary Ask: Run a 30–90 day pilot on one critical service to quantify impact. Week 0: Enable Copilot Spaces; capture baseline metrics (onboarding, Q&A load). Weeks 1–4+: Team uses Space; you track usage and outcomes; collect anecdotes. Readout: Show faster onboarding, fewer interrupts, better consistency; propose scale-out. Be ready for common objections “We already have a wiki.” → Wikis go stale. Spaces ties live code and docs to AI answers inside the dev workflow, with citations to original sources.[^5] “Can we trust the answers?” → Responses are grounded in your repos/docs; you curate sources and visibility. “Is this secure?” → Data stays in your GitHub tenancy; access respects repo governance and branch protection. “Is setup heavy?” → Connect key repos/docs in minutes; Spaces stay up to date automatically as code changes. Keep knowledge fresh Treat Spaces and .github/copilot-instructions.md as living assets—schedule monthly reviews. Pin authoritative docs and retire stale references so Copilot’s context remains trustworthy. Capture success stories: when Copilot resolves a question or an agent completes a task, feed the insights back into your instructions. Pair with Copilot Code Review to reinforce conventions at PR time and catch drift early.
